verses.text: Groaning and trembling shalt thou be on the earth".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 29:9
verses.text: From that time the earth, through fear, no longer receives human blood, no, nor the blood of any animal; by which it appears that it is not the cause of death, but man, who transgressed.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 30—Cain's Family and Their Inventions.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:2
verses.text: Cain also himself had a son, whose name was Enoch; and he built a city, which he called by the name of his son, Enoch.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:3
verses.text: From that time was there made a beginning of the building of cities, and this before the flood; not as Homer falsely says:—  "Not yet had men a city built".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:4
verses.text: And to Enoch was born a son, by name Gaidad; who begat a son called Meel; and Meel begat Mathusala; and Mathusala, Lamech.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:5
verses.text: And Lamech took unto him two wives, whose names were Adah and Zillah.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:6
verses.text: At that time there was made a beginning of polygamy, and also of music.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:7
verses.text: For Lamech had three sons: Jabal, Jubal, Tubal.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:8
verses.text: And Jabal became a keeper of cattle, and dwelt in tents; but Jubal is he who made known the psaltery and the harp; and Tubal became a smith, a forger in brass and iron.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:9
verses.text: So far the seed of Cain is registered; and for the rest, the seed of his line has sunk into oblivion, on account of his fratricide of his brother.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:10
verses.text: And, in place of Abel, God granted to Eve to conceive and bear a son, who was called Seth; from whom the remainder of the human race proceeds until now.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:11
verses.text: And to those who desire to be informed regarding all generations, it is easy to give explanations by means of the holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:12
verses.text: For, as we have already mentioned, this subject, the order of the genealogy of man, has been partly handled by us in another discourse, in the first book of The History.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:13
verses.text: And all these things the Holy Spirit teaches us, who speaks through Moses and the rest of the prophets, so that the writings which belong to us godly people are more ancient, yea, and are shown to be more truthful, than all writers and poets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:14
verses.text: But also, concerning music, some have fabled that Apollo was the inventor, and others say that Orpheus discovered the art of music from the sweet voices of the birds.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:15
verses.text: Their story is shown to be empty and vain, for these inventors lived many years after the flood.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 30:16
verses.text: And what relates to Noah, who is called by some Deucalion, has been explained by us in the book before mentioned, and which, if you wish it, you are at liberty to read.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:1
verses.text: Chapter 31—The History After the Flood.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:2
verses.text: After the flood was there again a beginning of cities and kings, in the following manner:—The first city was Babylon, and Erech, and Accad, and Calneh, in the land of Shinar.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:3
verses.text: And their king was called Nebroth Nimrod.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:4
verses.text: From these came Asshur, from whom also the Assyrians receive their name.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:5
verses.text: And Nimrod built the cities Nineveh and Rehoboth, and Calah, and Resen, between Nineveh and Calah; and Nineveh became a very great city.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:6
verses.text: And another son of Shem, the son of Noah, by name Mizraim, begat Ludim, and those called Anamim, and Lehabim, and Naphtuhim, and Pathrusim, and Casluhim, out of whom came Philistin.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:7
verses.text: Of the three sons of Noah, however, and of their death and genealogy, we have given a compendious register in the above-mentioned book.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:8
verses.text: But now we will mention the remaining facts both concerning cities and kings, and the things that happened when there was one speech and one language.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:9
verses.text: Before the dividing of the languages these fore-mentioned cities existed.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:10
verses.text: But when men were about to be dispersed, they took counsel of their own judgment, and not at the instigation of God, to build a city, a tower whose top might reach into heaven, that they might make a glorious name to themselves.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:11
verses.text: Since, therefore, they had dared, contrary to the will of God, to attempt a grand work, God destroyed their city, and overthrew their tower.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:12
verses.text: From that time He confounded the languages of men, giving to each a different dialect.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:13
verses.text: And similarly did the Sibyl speak, when she declared that wrath would come on the world.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:14
verses.text: She says:—  "When are fulfilled the threats of the great God, With which He threatened men, when formerly In the Assyrian land they built a tower, And all were of one speech, and wished to rise Even till they climbed unto the starry heaven, Then the Immortal raised a mighty wind And laid upon them strong necessity; For when the wind threw down the mighty tower, Then rose among mankind fierce strife and hate.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:15
verses.text: One speech was changed to many dialects, And earth was filled with divers tribes and kings".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:16
verses.text: And so on.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:17
verses.text: These things, then, happened in the land of the Chaldaeans.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:18
verses.text: And in the land of Canaan there was a city, by name Haran.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:19
verses.text: And in these days, Pharaoh, who by the Egyptians was also called Nechaoth, was first king of Egypt, and thus the kings followed in succession.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:20
verses.text: And in the land of Shinar, among those called Chaldaeans,  the first king was Arioch, and next after him Ellasar, and after him Chedorlaomer, king of Elam, and after him Tidal, king of the nations called Assyrians.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:21
verses.text: And there were five other cities in the territory of Ham, the son of Noah; the first called Sodom, then Gomorrah, Admah, Zeboiim, and Balah, which was also called Zoar.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:22
verses.text: And the names of their kings are these: Bera, king of Sodom; Birsha, king of Gomorrah; Shinab, king of Admah; Shemeber, king of Zeboiim; Bela, king of Zoar, which is also called Kephalac.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:23
verses.text: These served Chedorlaomer, the king of the Assyrians, for twelve years, and in the thirteenth year they revolted from Chedorlaomer; and thus it came to pass at that time that the four Assyrian kings waged war upon the five kings.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:24
verses.text: This was the first commencement of making war on the earth; and they destroyed the giants Karnaim, and the strong nations that were with them in their city, and the Horites of the mountains called Seir, as far as the plain of Paran, which is by the wilderness.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:25
verses.text: And at that time there was a righteous king called Melchisedek, in the city of Salem, which now is Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:26
verses.text: This was the first priest of all priests of the Most High God; and from him the above-named city Hierosolyma was called Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:27
verses.text: And from his time priests were found in all the earth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:28
verses.text: And after him reigned Abimelech in Gerar; and after him another Abimelech.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:29
verses.text: Then reigned Ephron, surnamed the Hittite.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:30
verses.text: Such are the names of the kings that were in former times.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:31
verses.text: And the rest of the kings of the Assyrians, during an interval of many years, have been passed over in silence unrecorded, all writers narrating the events of our recent days.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 31:32
verses.text: There were these kings of Assyria: Tiglath-Pileser, and after him Shalmaneser, then Sennacherib; and Adrammelech the Ethiopian, who also reigned over Egypt, was his triarch;—though these things, in comparison with our books, are quite recent.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 32:1
verses.text: Chapter 32—How the Human Race Was Dispersed.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 32:2
verses.text: Hence, therefore, may the loves of learning and of antiquity understand the history, and see that those things are recent which are told by us apart from the holy prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 32:3
verses.text: For though at first there were few men in the land of Arabia and Chaldaea, yet, after their languages were divided, they gradually began to multiply and spread over all the earth; and some of them tended towards the east to dwell there, and others to the parts of the great continent, and others northwards, so as to extend as far as Britain, in the Arctic regions.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 32:4
verses.text: And others went to the land of Canaan, which is called Judaea, and Phoenicia, and the region of Ethiopia, and Egypt, and Libya, and the country called torrid, and the parts stretching towards the west; and the rest went to places by the sea, and Pamphylia, and Asia, and Greece, and Macedonia, and, besides, to Italy, and the whole country called Gaul, and Spain, and Germany; so that now the whole world is thus filled with inhabitants.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 32:5
verses.text: Since then the occupation of the world by men was at first in three divisions,—in the east, and south, and west: afterwards, the remaining parts of the earth were inhabited, when men became very numerous.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 32:6
verses.text: And the writers, not knowing these things, are forward to maintain that the world is shaped like a sphere, and to compare it to a cube.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 32:7
verses.text: But how can they say what is true regarding these things, when they do not know about the creation of the world and its population? Men gradually increasing in number and multiplying on the earth, as we have already said, the islands also of the sea and the rest of the countries were inhabited.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 33:1
verses.text: Chapter 33—Profane History Gives No Account of These Matters.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 33:2
verses.text: Who, then, of those called sages, and poets, and historians, could tell us truly of these things, themselves being much later born, and introducing a multitude of gods, who were born so many years after the cities, and are more modern than kings, and nations, and wars? For they should have made mention of all events, even those which happened before the flood; both of the creation of the world and the formation of man, and the whole succession of events.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 33:3
verses.text: The Egyptian or Chaldaean prophets, and the other writers, should have been able accurately to tell, if at least they spoke by a divine and pure spirit, and spoke truth in all that was uttered by them; and they should have announced not only things past or present, but also those that were to come upon the world.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 33:4
verses.text: And therefore it is proved that all others have been in error; and that we Christians alone have possessed the truth, inasmuch as we are taught by the Holy Spirit, who spoke in the holy prophets, and foretold all things.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 34:1
verses.text: Chapter 34—The Prophets Enjoined Holiness of Life.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 34:2
verses.text: And, for the rest, would that in a kindly spirit you would investigate divine things—I mean the things that are spoken by the prophets—in order that, by comparing what is said by us with the utterances of the others, you may be able to discover the truth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 34:3
verses.text: We have shown from their own histories, which they have compiled, that the names of those who are called gods, are found to be the names of men who lived among them, as we have shown above.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 34:4
verses.text: And to this day their images are daily fashioned, idols, "the works of men's hands".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 34:5
verses.text: And these the mass of foolish men serve, whilst they reject the maker and fashioner of all things and the nourisher of all breath of life, giving credit to vain doctrines through the deceitfulness of the senseless tradition received from their fathers.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 34:6
verses.text: But God at least, the Father and Creator of the universe, did not abandon mankind, but gave a law, and sent holy prophets to declare and teach the race of men, that each one of us might awake and understand that there is one God.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 34:7
verses.text: And they also taught us to refrain from unlawful idolatry, and adultery, and murder, fornication, theft, avarice, false swearing, wrath, and every incontinence and uncleanness; and that whatever a man would not wish to be done to himself, he should not do to another; and thus he who acts righteously shall escape the eternal punishments, and be thought worthy of the eternal life from God.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:1
verses.text: Chapter 35—Precepts from the Prophetic Books.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:2
verses.text: The divine law, then, not only forbids the worshipping of idols, but also of the heavenly bodies, the sun, the moon, or the other stars; yea, not heaven, nor earth, nor the sea, nor fountains, nor rivers, must be worshipped, but we must serve in holiness of heart and sincerity of purpose only the living and true God, who also is Maker of the universe.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:3
verses.text: Wherefore saith the holy law: "Thou shalt not commit adultery; thou shalt not steal; thou shalt not bear false witness; thou shalt not desire thy neighbour's wife".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:4
verses.text: So also the prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:5
verses.text: Solomon indeed teaches us that we must not sin with so much as a turn of the eye, saying, "Let thine eyes look right on, and let thy eyelids look straight before thee".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:6
verses.text: And Moses, who himself also was a prophet, says, concerning the sole government of God: "Your God is He who establishes the heaven, and forms the earth, whose hands have brought forth all the host of heaven; and He has not set these things before you that you should go after them".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:7
verses.text: And Isaiah himself also says: "Thus saith the Lord God who established the heavens, and founded the earth and all that is therein, and giveth breath unto the people upon it, and spirit to them that walk therein.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:8
verses.text: This is the Lord your God".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:9
verses.text: And again, through him He says: "I have made the earth, and man upon it.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:10
verses.text: I by my hand have established the heavens".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:11
verses.text: And in another chapter, "This is your God, who created the ends of the earth; He hungereth not, neither is weary, and there is no searching of His understanding".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:12
verses.text: So, too, Jeremiah says: "Who hath made the earth by His power, and established the world by His wisdom, and by His discretion hath stretched out the heavens, and a mass of water in the heavens, and He caused the clouds to ascend from the ends of the earth; He made lightnings with rain, and brought forth winds out of His treasures".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:13
verses.text: One can see how consistently and harmoniously all the prophets spoke, having given utterance through one and the same spirit concerning the unity of God, and the creation of the world, and the formation of man.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:14
verses.text: Moreover, they were in sore travail, bewailing the godless race of men, and they reproached those, who seemed to be wise, for their error and hardness of heart.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:15
verses.text: Jeremiah, indeed, said: "Every man is brutishly gone astray from the knowledge of Him; every founder is confounded by his graven images; in vain the silversmith makes his molten images; there is no breath in them: in the day of their visitation they shall perish".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:16
verses.text: The same, too, says David: "They are corrupt, they have done abominable works; there is none that doeth good, no, not one; they have all gone aside, they have together become profitless".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:17
verses.text: So also Habakkuk: "What profiteth the graven image that he has graven it a lying image? Woe to him that saith to the stone, Awake; and to the wood, Arise".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:18
verses.text: Likewise spoke the other prophets of the truth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:19
verses.text: And why should I recount the multitude of prophets, who are numerous, and said ten thousand things consistently and harmoniously? For those who desire it, can, by reading what they uttered, accurately understand the truth, and no longer be carried away by opinion and profitless labour.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 35:20
verses.text: These, then, whom we have already mentioned, were prophets among the Hebrews,—illiterate, and shepherds, and uneducated.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:1
verses.text: Chapter 36—Prophecies of the Sibyl.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:2
verses.text: And the Sibyl, who was a prophetess among the Greeks and the other nations, in the beginning of her prophecy, reproaches the race of men, saying:—  "How are ye still so quickly lifted up, And how so thoughtless of the end of life, Ye mortal men of flesh, who are but nought? Do ye not tremble, nor fear God most high? Your Overseer, the Knower, Seer of all, Who ever keeps those whom His hand first made, Puts His sweet Spirit into all His works, And gives Him for a guide to mortal men.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:3
verses.text: There is one only uncreated God, Who reigns alone, all-powerful, very great, From whom is nothing hid.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:4
verses.text: He sees all things, Himself unseen by any mortal eye.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:5
verses.text: Can mortal man see the immortal God, Or fleshly eyes, which shun the noontide beams, Look upon Him, who dwells beyond the heavens? Worship Him then, the self-existent God, The unbegotten Ruler of the world, Who only was from everlasting time, And shall to everlasting still abide.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:6
verses.text: Of evil counsels ye shall reap the fruit, Because ye have not honoured the true God, Nor offered to Him sacred hecatombs.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:7
verses.text: To those who dwell in Hades ye make gifts, And unto demons offer sacrifice.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:8
verses.text: In madness and in pride ye have your walk; And leaving the right way, ye wander wide, And lose yourselves in pitfalls and in thorns.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:9
verses.text: Why do ye wander thus, O foolish men? Cease your vain wanderings in the black, dark night; Why follow darkness and perpetual gloom When, see, there shines for you the blessed light? Lo, He is clear—in Him there is no spot.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:10
verses.text: Turn, then, from darkness, and behold the day; Be wise, and treasure wisdom in your breasts.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:11
verses.text: There is one God who sends the winds and rains, The earthquakes, and the lightnings, and the plagues, The famines, and the snow-storms, and the ice, And all the woes that visit our sad race.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:12
verses.text: Nor these alone, but all things else He gives, Ruling omnipotent in heaven and earth, And self-existent from eternity".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:13
verses.text: And regarding those gods that are said to have been born, she said:—  "If all things that are born must also die, "God cannot be produced by mortal man.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:14
verses.text: But there is only One, the All-Supreme, Who made the heavens, with all their starry host, The sun and moon; likewise the fruitful earth, With all the waves of ocean, and the hills, The fountains, and the ever flowing streams; He also made the countless multitude Of ocean creatures, and He keeps alive All creeping things, both of the earth and sea; And all the tuneful choir of birds He made, Which cleave the air with wings, and with shrill pipe Trill forth at morn their tender, clear-voiced song.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:15
verses.text: Within the deep glades of the hills He placed A savage race of beasts; and unto men He made all cattle subject, making man The God-formed image, ruler over all, And putting in subjection to his sway Things many and incomprehensible.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:16
verses.text: For who of mortals can know all these things? He only knows who made them at the first, He the Creator, incorruptible, Who dwells in upper air eternally; Who proffers to the good most rich rewards, And against evil and unrighteous men Rouses revenge, and wrath, and bloody wars, And pestilence, and many a tearful grief.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:17
verses.text: O man exalted vainly—say why thus Hast thou so utterly destroyed thyself? Have ye no shame worshipping beasts for gods? And to believe the gods should steal your beasts, Or that they need your vessels—is it not Frenzy's most profitless and foolish thought? Instead of dwelling in the golden heavens, Ye see your gods become the prey of worms, And hosts of creatures noisome and unclean.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:18
verses.text: O fools! ye worship serpents, dogs, and cats, Birds, and the creeping things of earth and sea, Images made with hands, statues of stone, And heaps of rubbish by the wayside placed.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:19
verses.text: All these, and many more vain things, ye serve, Worshipping things disgraceful even to name: These are the gods who lead vain men astray, From whose mouth streams of deadly poison flow.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:20
verses.text: But unto Him in whom alone is life, Life, and undying, everlasting light; Who pours into man's cup of life a joy Sweeter than sweetest honey to his taste,— Unto Him bow the head, to Him alone, And walk in ways of everlasting peace.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:21
verses.text: Forsaking Him, ye all have turned aside, And, in your raving folly, drained the cup Of justice quite unmixed, pure, mastering, strong; And ye will not again be sober men, Ye will not come unto a sober mind, And know your God and King, who looks on all: Therefore, upon you burning fire shall come, And ever ye shall daily burn in flames, Ashamed for ever of your useless gods.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:22
verses.text: But those who worship the eternal God, They shall inherit everlasting life, Inhabiting the blooming realms of bliss, And feasting on sweet food from starry heaven".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:23
verses.text: That these things are true, and useful, and just, and profitable to all men, is obvious.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 36:24
verses.text: Even the poets have spoken of the punishments of the wicked.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:1
verses.text: Chapter 37—The Testimonies of the Poets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:2
verses.text: And that evil-doers must necessarily be punished in proportion to their deeds, has already been, as it were, oracularly uttered by some of the poets, as a witness both against themselves and against the wicked, declaring that they shall be punished.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:3
verses.text: aeschylus said:—  "He who has done must also suffer".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:4
verses.text: And Pindar himself said:—  "It is fit that suffering follow doing".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:5
verses.text: So, too, Euripides:—  "The deed rejoiced you—suffering endure; The taken enemy must needs be pain'd".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:6
verses.text: And again:—  "The foe's pain is the hero's meed".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:7
verses.text: And, similarly, Archilochus:—  "One thing I know, I hold it ever true, The evil-doer evil shall endure".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:8
verses.text: And that God sees all, and that nothing escapes His notice, but that, being long-suffering, He refrains until the time when He is to judge—concerning this, too, Dionysius said:—  "The eye of Justice seeing all, Yet seemeth not to see".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:9
verses.text: And that God's judgment is to be, and that evils will suddenly overtake the wicked,—this, too, aeschylus declared, saying:—  "Swift-footed is the approach of fate, And none can justice violate, But feels its stern hand soon or late.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:10
verses.text: "'Tis with you, though unheard, unseen; You draw night's curtain in between, But even sleep affords no screen.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:11
verses.text: "'Tis with you if you sleep or wake; And if abroad your way you take, Its still, stern watch you cannot break.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:12
verses.text: "'Twill follow you, or cross your path; And even night no virtue hath To hide you from th' Avenger's wrath.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:13
verses.text: "To show the ill the darkness flees; Then, if sin offers joy or ease, Oh stop, and think that some one sees!"  And may we not cite Simonides also?—  "To men no evil comes unheralded; But God with sudden hand transforms all things".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:14
verses.text: Euripides again:—  "The wicked and proud man's prosperity Is based on sand: his race abideth not; And time proclaims the wickedness of men".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:15
verses.text: Once more Euripides:—  "Not without judgment is the Deity, But sees when oaths are struck unrighteously, And when from men unwilling they are wrung".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:16
verses.text: And Sophocles:—  "If ills you do, ills also you must bear".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:17
verses.text: That God will make inquiry both concerning false swearing and concerning every other wickedness, they themselves have well-nigh predicted.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:18
verses.text: And concerning the conflagration of the world, they have, willingly or unwillingly, spoken in conformity with the prophets, though they were much more recent, and stole these things from the law and the prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 37:19
verses.text: The poets corroborate the testimony of the prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:1
verses.text: Chapter 38—The Teachings of the Greek Poets and Philosophers Confirmatory of Those of the Hebrew Prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:2
verses.text: But what matters it whether they were before or after them? Certainly they did at all events utter things confirmatory of the prophets.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:3
verses.text: Concerning the burning up of the world, Malachi the prophet foretold: "The day of the Lord cometh as a burning oven, and shall consume all the wicked".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:4
verses.text: And Isaiah: "For the wrath of God is as a violent hail-storm, and as a rushing mountain torrent".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:5
verses.text: The Sibyl, then, and the other prophets, yea, and the poets and philosophers, have clearly taught both concerning righteousness, and judgment, and punishment; and also concerning providence, that God cares for us, not only for the living among us, but also for those that are dead: though, indeed, they said this unwillingly, for they were convinced by the truth.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:6
verses.text: And among the prophets indeed, Solomon said of the dead, "There shall be healing to thy flesh, and care taken of thy bones".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:7
verses.text: And the same says David, "The bones which Thou hast broken shall rejoice".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:8
verses.text: And in agreement with these sayings was that of Timocles:—  "The dead are pitied by the loving God".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:9
verses.text: And the writers who spoke of a multiplicity of gods came at length to the doctrine of the unity of God, and those who asserted chance spoke also of providence; and the advocates of impunity confessed there would be a judgment, and those who denied that there is a sensation after death acknowledged that there is.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:10
verses.text: Homer, accordingly, though he had said,—  "Like fleeting vision passed the soul away,"  says in another place:—  "To Hades went the disembodied soul;"  And again:—  "That I may quickly pass through Hades' gates, Me bury".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:11
verses.text: And as regards the others whom you have read, I think you know with sufficient accuracy how they have expressed themselves.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:12
verses.text: But all these things will every one understand who seeks the wisdom of God, and is well pleasing to Him through faith and righteousness and the doing of good works.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:13
verses.text: For one of the prophets whom we already mentioned, Hosea by name, said, "Who is wise, and he shall understand these things? prudent, and he shall know them? for the ways of the Lord are right, and the just shall walk in them: but the transgressors shall fall therein".

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:14
verses.text: He, then, who is desirous of learning, should learn much.

verses.name: Theohpilus: To Autolycus Book II 38:15
verses.text: Endeavour therefore to meet with me more frequently, that, by hearing the living voice, you may accurately ascertain the truth.
